source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description: Prepare cleaned workspace with all necessary reagents and equipment.

source.body: If lab-wide large-batch pre-prepared reagent stores are used, ensure to have made personal stock-aliquot of reagents such as UV-Water, EDTA, sodium acetate, and proteinase K in amounts sufficient for this extraction.

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description: Weigh GuHCl and transfer into a glass bottle.

source.body: If you want to clean the area where GuHCl was used, first use water and then bleach solution. Do not use bleach directly as it reacts with GuHCl to produce toxic chlorine gas!

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description: Add UV-irradiated HPLC water (6 mL).

source.body: This reaction is endothermic and the tube will become very cold. Be aware of the unusual 'slushy' way of dissolving.

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Gently shake horizontally in order to get the salt dissolved. If necessary, apply short (
) bursts in microwave (~400W) keeping the tube slightly unscrewed. Wait until bottle cools down between microwave bursts.

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Pipette isopropanol (4 mL) to reach the final reaction volume (
).

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Prepare wash buffer by pipetting
ethanol to the wash buffer from the High Pure Viral Nucleic Acid kit following manufacturer's instuctions and make an aliquot calculating
.

source.title: / reaction
Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Prepare TET elution buffer by making an aliquot of TE-buffer calculating
and pipette Tween-20 accordingly to reach
concentration to make 'TET'.

source.title: / reaction

source.body: Because Tween-20 is highly viscous, we dilute it 1:10 in UV-HPLC water, and use this 10% dilution to add Tween-20 to the TE-buffer

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Irradiate all buffers with UV for
without the lids.

source.body: UV irradiation can be done together with solutions from steps 1 (binding buffer), 4 (wash buffer), and 5 (TET buffer).

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Store binding buffer in a fridge at
overnight for day 4.

source.body: Label the bottle accordingly with the name, date and for the calculated amount of reactions. Buffer can be stored in a fridge for up to four weeks. Seal bottle with parafilm to avoid evaporation.

source.title: Day 1: Preparation of reagents (Buffer Prep Room)

source.description:
Dilute proteinase K powder (
) in
UV HPLC-water to a working concentration of
/
.

source.body: Store proteinase K solution at for use on day 2.

source.title: Day 1: Sample decontamination (DNA extraction room)

source.description:
UV sterilize calculus. Irradiate samples for
, then shake the samples and irradiate for another
.

source.body: Aim for 2-5 mg starting material.
If the sample is in powder-form, irradiate in the original tube with the lid open. If the sample is in large pieces, place calculus in an aluminium foil boat in the crosslinker to maximize exposure.

source.title: Day 1: Decalcification (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Add
of fresh 0.5 M EDTA to each sample pellet.

source.title: Day 1: Decalcification (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Seal tubes with Parafilm, rotate
with low overhead rotation speed (e.g., 12-16 rpm) at room temperature. If the tubes will be exposed to UV irridation, such as whole-room irridation for sterilization, be sure to cover them with foil or otherwise shield them.

source.body: Post-incubation sample suspended in EDTA can safely be stored in a freezer ( ) before isolation and clean-up.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
For each reaction prepare one
Falcon tube, one High Pure Extender Assembly (i.e. Falcon tube from kit containing funnel and purification column), two collection tubes from the kit, and one
LoBind tube for final elution step.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
In every
Falcon tube pipette
binding buffer and
sodium acetate (UV-irradiated). Mix by inversion and measure pH (should be 5-6).

source.body: Add more sodium acetate if the pH is too high. If the pH is too low you can add sodium hydroxide.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Remove parafilm from extraction tubes, then spin the tubes for
at
to pellet calculus.

source.body: If pellet is not solid, repeat centrifugation.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Pipette supernatant to respective
Falcon tube, mix contents by inversion. If pellet is too fragile, repeat centrifugation before transferring supernatant. Store the calculus pellet at
.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Pipette binding buffer/extract mix to High Pure Extender Assembly.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Spin at a maximum of
for

source.body: This RPM is specific to a 50 mL Thermo Scientific TX-400 Swinging Bucket Rotor. As this is a swing rotor, the rpm value maybe inconsistent for other models. Therefore this value must be adjusted on a per-machine basis. Convert the rpm to rcf (g) and determine the appropriate rpm for your instrument.
You can also turn the tube 180o after to ensure the liquid does not get stuck on the inner rim of the funnel
During this centrifugation step, we recommend preparing downstream steps, such as labelling of final elution tubes.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Pipette any liquids remaining in the funnel onto the column. Remove funnel from column and insert the column into a fresh 2 mL collection tube.

source.body: The flow-through stays in the collection tube of the 50mL High Pure Extender Assembly and can be discarded.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Dry spin the column in the collection tube for
at
.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Pipette
wash buffer from the High Pure Viral Nucleic Acid kit to the column, and spin at
for
.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Remove column from the collection tube, discard the flow-through and the old collection tube, and put the column into a fresh 2 mL collection tube.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Repeat washing step once (
) reusing the collection tube, and discard flow-through.

source.body:
Discard flow-through in one of two following ways:
  • Remove all liquid in the collection tube with a pipette, or
  • Pour off the liquid into a fresh waste tube, and pat the rim of the collection tube dry on a paper tissue or towl. Use just one spot on the paper tissue per sample. Be careful not to touch the rim of the tube on the waste container. Be sure to clean the surface with DNA Away or bleach after discarding the paper.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Dry spin at
for

source.body: To ensure the liquid does not get stuck on the inner rim of the funnel, you can optionally spin for , turn the tube 180o, and dry spin for another

source.title: Day 4: Elution (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Transfer column to a fresh
LoBind Tube, pipette
of Tris-EDTA-tween (TET) to the center of column, incubate for
on the benchtop, and spin
at
to elute the DNA.

source.body: Eluted DNA will be stored in this tube. Label tube on top and side accordingly.

source.title: Day 4: Elution (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Repeat elution step for a total elution volume of
TET.

source.title: Day 4: Elution (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Store the DNA extracts at
.

source.title: Day 1: Sample decontamination (DNA extraction room)

source.description:
If the calculus was in a boat for irradiation place it back in a 1.5 mL or 2 mL tube. Add
of 0.5 M EDTA to each sample, to remove surface contaminants.

source.body: This step can be skipped if the purpose of the study is to detect infectuous pathogens, as these are more likely to be located on the outer layer of the calculus deposit (however, this may lead to a higher proportion of environmental contaminants in the data).

source.title: Day 1: Sample decontamination (DNA extraction room)

source.description:
Vortex and incubate on rotator at room temperature for
.

source.body: The incubation step can lead to some sample loss, as the calculus will start dissolving and releasing DNA. If the calculus is very powdery, the supernatant can be removed directly after vortexing, without any incubation. Otherwise the calculus solubilizes within the 15 min and you lose DNA while removing the EDTA.

source.title: Day 1: Sample decontamination (DNA extraction room)

source.description:
Spin tubes
at
.

source.title: Day 1: Sample decontamination (DNA extraction room)

source.description:
Transfer supernatant to a separate tube, labelled "EDTA-wash". Store the "EDTA-wash" tube at
for potential future analyses.

source.title: Day 2-3: Protein digestion (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Remove Parafilm and make sure that the tubes have not leaked (if they have leaked, clean them).

source.body: The appearance of the calculus will vary depending on its initial state. Larger pieces will have barely changed at all, while powder will be almost gone.

source.title: Day 2-3: Protein digestion (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Briefly centrifuge tubes to remove any liquid from the lids.

source.title: Day 2-3: Protein digestion (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description:
Add
of 10 mg/ml proteinase K to each tube.

source.title: Day 2-3: Protein digestion (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Vortex tubes, seal with Parafilm, and continue decalcification by rotating at low overhead rotation speed (e.g., 12-16 rpm) at room temperature for 24-48 hours.

source.body: After starting the incubation, we recommend beginning preparations for day 4, such as pre-labelling the falcon tubes that will be used in step 17.

Decalcification time can be adapted, so that the sample is completely decalcified before starting DNA isolation. After complete decalcification, the sample should appear buoyant and feathery, or disappear altogether.
Post-incubation suspension can safely be stored in a freezer ( ) before isolation and clean-up.

source.title: Day 4: DNA isolation and clean-up (DNA Extraction Room)

source.description: Prepare cleaned workspace with all necessary reagents and equipment.

materials.name: Safe-Lock Tubes 1.5 ml PCR clean DNA LoBind
Safe-Lock Tubes 2 ml PCR clean DNA LoBind
50 ml CELLSTAR® Polypropylene Tube 30/115 MM Conical Bottom Blue screw cap sterile skirt
Proteinase K from Tritirachium album lyophilized powder >=30 units/mg protein
Sodium Acetate buffer solution 3 M pH 52 for molecular biology
TE buffer (1X) pH 8.0 low EDTA for molecular biology 500ml
TWEEN 20 for molecular biology viscous liquid
High Pure Viral Nucleic Acid Large Volume Kit

description: Silica-based total DNA extraction protocol optimised for the recovery of ultra-short DNA molecules from archaeological dental calculus, modified from Dabney et al. (2013) PNAS (doi: 10.1073/pnas.1314445110) and adapted for dental calculus by Mann et al. (2018) Scientific Reports (doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-28091-9).
